I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan, and (ii) a proposed grant, both to Nepal for the Integrated Urban Development Project.1 
 
2.  The  project  will  provide  the  population  in  the  municipalities  of  Dharan,  Janakpur, 
Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar with better access to municipal infrastructure and services in a 
socially inclusive manner.2 In accordance with the priorities of each municipality, integrated 
urban  environmental  improvements,  including  drainage  systems,  solid  waste  management 
(SWM)  facilities,  and  urban  roads,  will  be  implemented  in  Janakpur,  Nepalgunj,  and 
Siddharthanagar municipalities. A water supply development subproject will be implemented in 
Dharan municipality. The project will also undertake community development programs (CDPs), 
focusing primarily on poverty pockets in the municipalities and communities that may not benefit 
directly from major infrastructure improvement subprojects. Gender equality and social inclusion 
(GESI) will be mainstreamed in all subprojects in the municipalities, and the capacity to address 
GESI  in  the  Ministry  of  Physical  Planning  and  Works  (MPPW)  will  be  strengthened  by 
establishing an appropriate institutional structure and mechanisms for GESI mainstreaming. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The pace of urbanization in Nepal has increased markedly during 2001–2011 with an 
urban population growth rate of 3.4% per annum, compared with national population growth of 
1.4% per annum. In 2011, 17% of the population was estimated to live in urban areas, up from 
9.2%  in  1991  and  13.9%  in  2001.  While  global  experience  clearly  demonstrates  that 
urbanization  is  an  important  driver  of  economic  development,  the  potential  has  not  been 
adequately tapped in Nepal. In the absence of a stringent policy regulating and managing 
growth,  uncontrolled  and  haphazard  urban  development  has  created  numerous  problems, 
including deficiencies in basic urban services; environmental degradation; encroachment on 
public land, forests, and river banks; and sprawling settlement development. Most municipalities 
in  Nepal  lack  properly  engineered  and  operated  sanitary  landfills,  and  have  limited  and 
intermittent  water  supply  services,  poorly  maintained  road  infrastructure,  and  inadequate 
drainage systems that cause recurrent waterlogging problems, mainly in the Terai.3  The Local 
Self Governance Act mandates a wide range of functions and responsibilities to municipalities, 
but the lack of financial and qualified human resources and a low level of institutional capacity 
make providing infrastructure facilities commensurate with the growing demand for services a 
major challenge. Poor health, caused by the poor urban environment, saps economic growth by 
reducing labor productivity and educational attainment. Disease, associated economic burden, 
and premature death disproportionately affect the poor and vulnerable.  
 
4.  The National Urban Policy (NUP) adopted by the Government of Nepal in 2007 gives 
priority  to  (i)  achieving  a  balanced  national  urban  structure  by  directing  infrastructure 
development and investment;4 (ii) improving the quality of urban life through creation of a clean, 
safe, and well-developed urban environment; and (iii) setting up effective urban management by

empowering capable local institutions. Both the NUP and the government’s Three-Year Plan 
Approach Paper (FY2011–FY2013) place municipalities at the core of the urban development 
agenda,  and  support  strengthening  local  bodies,  so  they  can  effectively  implement  urban 
development plans and mobilize local resources. Although the policy intent is clear, effective 
implementation  of  the  policy  framework  is  hindered  by  numerous  problems,  including  the 
absence of people’s representatives in local bodies, lack of technical and skilled local-level 
manpower, failure to execute important aspects of decentralization and devolution, and lack of 
clarity  in  the  roles  of  and  collaboration  among  government  ministries,  local  bodies,  and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs). 
 
5.  Urban services are scarce outside Kathmandu Valley. Physical limitations restrict further 
development in the valley, and there is an urgent need to improve the environment in potential 
urban centers to promote social and economic development in other regions of Nepal. The 
government, represented by the Department of Urban Development and Building Construction 
(DUDBC), developed the criteria for selecting strategically important towns. Dharan, Janakpur, 
Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar were chosen for the project on the basis of (i) economic growth 
potential, (ii) demand for urban services, and (iii) urban management capacity.5 The project 
directly addresses and conforms to the development policy of Nepal, as expressed in the NUP 
and Three-Year Plan Approach Paper, by improving the environment of urban centers that work 
as catalysts for economic development, which will help contribute to the ―employment-centric, 
equitable, and inclusive economic growth‖ emphasized by the approach paper. 
 
6.  Urban infrastructure and facilities have tended not to fully recognize social differences in 
the needs of women, the poor, and excluded groups. People living in municipal poverty pockets 
experience  discrimination  based  on  gender,  caste,  and  ethnicity,  and  multiple  exclusions 
constrain their progress and access to services. Their participation in community activities is 
limited due to lack of access to information and resources, although progress has been made 
through support for their empowerment and mobilization from various NGOs and development 
partners. To be effective, urban development must integrate GESI. 
 
7.  The  project  is  in  line  with  the  Nepal  country  partnership  strategy  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB),6 which rests on four pillars: broad-based and inclusive economic 
growth, inclusive social development, governance and capacity building, and climate change 
adaptation  and  environmental  sustainability.  Reflecting  lessons  from  similar  projects,7 the 
project (i) focuses on a small number of physically integrated components, to simplify project 
administration and optimize inter-sector linkages; (ii) is confined to larger municipalities with 
relatively higher technical and financial capacity to implement the project and create discernable 
development  impacts;  (iii)  fully  involves  stakeholders,  including  communities,  in  project 
identification and design from an early stage; (iv) provides capacity development support before

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact will be the improved urban environment in the municipalities of Dharan, 
Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and Siddharthanagar. The outcome will be to provide population in these 
municipalities with better access to municipal infrastructure and services in a socially inclusive 
manner. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
9.  The project will have the following outputs. 
 
10.  Output  1:  Reliable  municipal  infrastructure  developed.  Subprojects  will  be 
implemented to develop reliable municipal infrastructure in accordance with the priorities set by 
the municipalities in their periodic plans.9 
 
11.  Drainage  and  roads. Three project municipalities on the flat land of the Terai are 
chronically waterlogged—particularly Nepalgunj and Siddhrthanagar, and to a lesser extent 
Janakpur—because  of  inadequate,  poorly  built,  and  poorly  maintained  drainage  and 
obstructions from solid waste dumping.10 There is no overall planning, leading to haphazard 
construction on a piecemeal basis, and drainage capacity is reduced in some natural drains due 
to encroachment. Pipes carrying untreated sewage effluent are often connected to the drainage 
system, causing bad odors and public health risks. These systems will be improved under a 
comprehensive drainage development plan to alleviate waterlogging and reduce the resulting 
damage to assets, economic activities, and human health. Future increases in rainfall intensity 
will be addressed during the drainage system detailed design to strengthen urban resilience to 
climate change. Urban roads are dilapidated, especially in Janakpur, and they will be restored 
or upgraded in areas where drainage network improvements are undertaken. 
 
12.  Solid waste management. Waste collection coverage in Janakpur is estimated at 40%, 
in Nepalgunj at 70%, and in Siddharthanagar at 56%. Without a sanitary landfill, collected waste 
is dumped haphazardly along riverbanks and into open spaces, causing pollution and public 
health hazards. Littering of waste in drains is common, segregation at source is rarely practiced, 
and waste recycling is far below the optimum level. The project will take an integrated approach 
to SWM by reviewing and improving the entire system, including (i) segregation and collection; 
(ii)  waste  reduction,  reuse,  and  recycling;  and  (iii)  transportation  and  final  disposal  at  the 
sanitary  landfill  site,  including  resource  recovery  facilities  in  Janakpur,  Nepalgunj,  and

Siddharthanagar.11 Strengthening waste reduction, reuse, and recycling will lead to a reduction 
in greenhouse gas emissions, and extend the service life of and reduce pollution risks at landfill 
sites. The possibility of private sector participation in SWM services (including landfill operation) 
will be explored by incorporating management services in the civil works contract to ensure 
effective and efficient operation of the system.12 
 
13.  Water  supply. As there is no known accessible groundwater in the town and very 
limited other reliable sources, there is complete dependence on the piped water supply system 
in Dharan. Dharan suffers low service levels provided by the Nepal Water Supply Corporation 
with only 4 hours per day of supply in the dry season.13 Water supply subproject in Dharan will 
include (i) development of new deep tubewells for water supply augmentation, (ii) rehabilitation 
and  replacement  of  existing  system  to  enhance  efficiency  including  non-revenue  water 
reduction, and (iii) expansion of the distribution network to increase the coverage to 95% from 
current 83%.  The project will support the establishment of Dharan Water Supply Management 
Board14 (DWSMB), which will take charge of operation and maintenance (O&M), including (i) 
asset valuation and transfer, (ii) institutional development including the drafting of regulations 
and a business plan, and (iii) system integration. 
 
14.  Consulting  services  for  design,  construction  supervision,  and  support  for  the  initial 
operation of facilities created under the project will be provided. The services will also include (i) 
support in setting and collecting adequate tariffs, taxes, and other charges to ensure sustainable 
O&M; and (ii) assessment of the appropriate O&M arrangement, particularly for integrated SWM 
facilities. 
 
15.  Output 2: Community development programs undertaken and gender equality and 
social  inclusion  capacity  strengthened.  This  output  will  be  achieved  through  the 
implementation of (i) CDPs in the project municipalities; and (ii) capacity development activities 
for gender  and social  inclusion  mainstreaming  in  the  MPPW,  its  three  departments,15 and 
project municipalities. The CDPs will mainly focus on poverty pockets in the municipalities and 
communities that may not benefit directly from major infrastructure improvement subprojects 
and will consist of (i) investment in small-scale community infrastructure chosen in accordance 
with the subproject selection criteria,16 such as public and community toilets, lane and drainage 
improvements,  community  composting  facilities,  and  community  water  taps;  (ii)  social 
mobilization  and  information,  education,  and  communication  campaigns  with  a  particular 
emphasis on health and hygiene education and waste reduction, reuse, and recycling activities; 
and (iii) skill and entrepreneurship development targeting women, the poor, and the excluded. A 
portion of the community infrastructure work may be used to support access by the poor to 
water supply and sanitation at the individual household level, such as private latrines and 
private connections to water supply services through performance-based grants such as output-
based aid. Activities pertaining to GESI will include (i) formation of structures and mechanisms 
for GESI mainstreaming in the MPPW and its departments; (ii) preparation of GESI operational 
manuals, toolkits, and checklists for road, water supply and sanitation, and urban development 
operations;  (iii)  technical  training  programs  for  MPPW  staff  and  departments,  and  project

16.  NGOs  will  be  engaged  by  the  municipalities  to  assist  in  CDP  implementation,  and 
consultants will be engaged by the MPPW for capacity development of the MPPW and its 
departments. Design and supervision consultants will assist in institutional strengthening of

17.  Output  3:  Project  management  and  administration  supported.  Support  will  be 
provided  for  smooth  and  effective  project  implementation  and  operation  by  the  central 
government and project municipalities. The project coordination office (PCO) in the DUDBC will 
manage overall project implementation, assisted by the project management support consultant. 
The project implementation units (PIUs) in each project municipality will implement infrastructure 
improvement and CDP. The GESI unit will be established in the MPPW to mainstream GESI in 
its operations and those of its three departments, with support from the consultants.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  Subproject selection considered priorities set by the municipalities and communities, 
basic minimum service requirements, affordability on the part of municipalities and beneficiaries, 
and capacity of the municipalities for implementation and O&M. In Janakpur, Nepalgunj, and 
Siddharthanagar, priority areas for drainage improvement were carefully selected to save costs 
while maintaining most benefits. Road improvements will be limited to areas where drainage is 
improved to ensure inter-sector complementarity. Although onsite sanitation systems with septic 
tanks are available in  all project municipalities, poorly working septic tanks  that discharge 
untreated wastewater into the drains are causing health risks, particularly by contaminating the 
shallow  groundwater  in  the  Terai.  Therefore,  the  project  municipalities  will  strengthen  the 
monitoring of regular septic tank cleaning, and a sludge drying bed will be constructed at the 
landfill site. In Dharan, an analysis concluded that the groundwater scheme for water supply 
augmentation is technically and financially more advantageous than the surface water scheme. 
A centralized wastewater management system is currently considered unnecessary because (i) 
the existing onsite systems are generally functioning well in Dharan, with improved monitoring of 
septic tank cleaning supported by the project; and (ii) there is no concern about groundwater 
contamination due to the depth of groundwater (about 200 meters). 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
23.  The public investment to be made under the project, including community infrastructure 
and programs to increase community awareness on public health and hygiene, will have a 
substantial impact on the urban environment and public health improvement. Economic benefits 
considered in the economic analysis were (i) savings in business losses, road maintenance 
costs, and property maintenance costs for the drainage system improvement; (ii) revenue from 
production of compost and recyclable materials and reduced health risks and medical expenses 
for the SWM improvement; (iii) savings in vehicle operating costs and travel time costs for the 
road system improvement; and (iv) non-incremental water sales in the form of resource cost

8 
savings, incremental water sales, and reduced medical expenses for the water supply system 
improvement. The results of the economic analysis show that all proposed subprojects were 
economically robust, with economic internal rates of return ranging from 14.6% to 39.5%, higher 
than the economic opportunity cost of capital. 
 
24.  Financial analysis was conducted only for the water supply system improvement in 
Dharan, as other subprojects will not be intended for direct cost recovery. The financial internal 
rate of return was estimated at 0.26%, which is nearly equal to the weighted average cost of 
capital, estimated at 0.30%.The low financial internal rate of return is the result of a balance 
between financial sustainability and affordability. However, even under the adverse conditions, 
the projected cash flow of Dharan municipality will be sufficient to cover O&M expenditure and 
debt service. For nonrevenue-generating subprojects, the analysis focused on financial capacity 
of  project municipalities  to meet  the recurrent  costs  required  to  operate  and maintain  the 
developed physical assets in a sustainable manner. An assessment of the financial position of 
the  municipalities  has  found  these  public  investments  to  be  financially  sustainable  with 
implementation  of  revenue-enhancement  measures  set  out  in  the  comprehensive  financial 
management improvement plan that each municipality is committed to implement (footnote 8). 
 
C.  Governance 
 
25.  An assessment of financial management and procurement capacity undertaken during 
project preparation indicates that DUDBC and TDF have a satisfactory record from previous 
projects and can effectively manage loan and grant proceeds for project implementation. While 
the project municipalities  lack experience on large-scale projects financed by development 
partners, the financial management risks are mitigated through capacity development technical 
assistance projects (footnote 8). Other risk-mitigation measures include (i) adequate training in 
ADB procedures for the municipal staff, and (ii) engagement of a procurement specialist and a 
financial management specialist as consultants to assist the municipalities. ADB and other 
development partners are supporting capacity building of relevant central government agencies 
to  strengthen  supervisory  functions  on  public  procurement.  Transparency  in  procurement, 
financing, and other matters will be maximized through measures that include (i) development 
by DUDBC of a project website, and (ii) local-level stakeholder consultations and information 
disclosure. 
 
26.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and municipalities. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
27.  The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. The support provided for 
GESI institutional capacity building is expected to enable MPPW to address poverty and social 
inequality issues. The improvements to be made by the project in water supply, drainage, and 
SWM  systems  will  produce  significant  public  health  benefits  to  the  community  in  general, 
including the poor. The CDP focuses on municipal poverty pockets, and women, the poor, and 
other  vulnerable  groups  will  benefit  from  small-scale  community  infrastructure,  a  social 
mobilization program, and skills and entrepreneurship development support. These programs 
will be implemented in a consultative and participatory manner with appropriate representation 
of women in the poor settlements. A GESI action plan with specific targets for all project 
activities will be implemented to ensure gender equality and social inclusiveness by addressing 
the different needs of women and vulnerable groups.

9 
E.  Safeguards 
 
28.  Environmental safeguards. The project is classified as environmental category B. Four 
initial environmental examinations including environmental management plans were prepared in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009)  and  government  laws,  and 
disclosed. Subprojects are not located in or near sensitive or protected areas, and the initial 
environmental examinations conclude that no significant adverse impacts are anticipated from 
proposed locations, designs, and construction activities. The environmental management plans 
provide adequate mitigation measures to ensure impacts are limited and of short duration. The 
net environmental benefits will be positive and large, including reduced (i) urban flooding from 
improved  drainage  systems,  and  (ii)  environmental  pollution  from  improved  SWM. 
Implementation  arrangements  in  the  PCO  build  on  experience gained  through  ADB  urban 
projects, and consultant support will enable the PIUs to manage environmental impacts. The 
PCO will provide environmental reports to ADB semiannually. An environmental assessment 
and  review  framework  was  prepared  to  address  small  components,  which  will  be  defined 
through detailed design, following approval by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
29.  Social safeguards. The project is classified as category B for involuntary resettlement 
and  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  Three  draft  resettlement  plans  were  prepared  in 
consultation with affected persons in accordance with the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
and disclosed. The project requires minor land acquisition for construction of sanitary landfills 
and temporary impacts on vendors during construction, with no significant resettlement impacts 
anticipated. Special assistance measures will be made available to vulnerable groups. The 
resettlement plans will be implemented by the PIUs and monitored by the PCO, and adequate 
consultant  inputs  will  be  made  available  to  support  implementation  and  build  capacity  to 
managing  resettlement  impacts  and  social  risks.  Considering  the  urban  locations  of  these 
subprojects, no impacts to indigenous peoples are expected. The draft resettlement framework 
was prepared to address small components, which will be defined through detailed design, 
following approval by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
31.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM 
and financing agreement. 
 
32.  The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are 
set forth in the financing and project agreements. 
 
33.  Conditions for effectiveness and first disbursement. Prior to the loan and grant 
effectiveness, the project agreement will have been duly executed and delivered on behalf of 
TDF and each of the municipalities and will have become fully effective and legally binding on 
the parties. Prior to the first disbursement of the loan in respect of any civil works and goods 
with respect to output 1, (i) the subsidiary loan agreement, satisfactory to ADB, will have been 
duly executed and delivered between the Ministry of Finance and TDF; and (ii) the standard 
form of onlending agreement, satisfactory to ADB, will have been finalized by TDF. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve 
(i)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR28,435,000 to Nepal for the 
Integrated Urban Development Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, 
with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period 
and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period 
of  8 years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft financing and project agreements 
presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the  grant  not  exceeding  $12,000,000  to  Nepal  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources  for  the  Integrated  Urban  Development  Project,  on  terms  and 
conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
financing and project agreements presented to the Board.
